facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 110 of 1970 filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL, APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 110 of 1970. Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 8th January 1970 of the Allahabad High Court  Lucknow

facts.text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 8th January 1970 of the Allahabad High Court Lucknow Bench in Criminal Appeal No. 634 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 8th January 1970 of the Allahabad High Court  Lucknow Bench  at Lucknow in Criminal Appeal No. 634 of 1967.

facts.text: Appellants, eleven in all, were acquitted by the Additional Sessions Judge, Gonda.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by CHANDRACHUD J.-The appellants, eleven in all, were acquitted by the Additional Sessions Judge, Gonda, but the order of acquittal was set aside in appeal by the High

facts.text: Allahabad High Court Lucknow Bench set aside the order of acquittal and convicted the appellants under sections 302, 325 and 323 read with section 149 and under section 147 of the Penal Code.

facts.text: Appellants sentenced to life imprisonment for murder and shorter terms for other offences.

anchor.surface_text: offence of murder and to shorter terms for the other offences. This appeal by special leave is directed against that judgment. The charge against the appellants is that on the evening of September 17, 1966

facts.text: Charge: On the evening of September 17, 1966, appellants formed an unlawful assembly and caused death of Hausla Prasad and injuries to Rampher, Dwarika and Lakhu.

issues.text: the precise scope of the power of this Court in criminal appeals by special leave from the judgments of High Courts setting aside acquittals

anchor.surface_text: The question as regards the power of this Court in criminal appeals by special leave from the judgments of High Courts setting aside acquittals has been discussed in numerous cases but the precise scope of that power is still being debated as a live issue.

issues.text: if the High Court has failed to apply correctly the principles governing appeals against acquittal

anchor.surface_text: The true position is that if the High Court has set aside an order of acquittal, this Court in an appeal under article 136 from the judgment of the High Court will examine the evidence only if the High Court has failed to apply correctly the principles governing appeals against acquittal.

issues.text: whether the view taken by the trial court was clearly unreasonable or perverse

anchor.surface_text: the golden thread running through all these decisions is the rule that in deciding appeals against acquittal the Court of Appeal must examine the evidence with particular care, must examine also the reasons on which the order of acquittal was based and should interfere with the order only when satisfied that the view taken by the acquitting Judge is clearly unreasonable.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in the instant case was evidently aware of these principles but it failed to apply them to the case on hand.

holdings.text: If the High Court has set aside an order of acquittal, this Court in an appeal under article 136 from the judgment of the High Court will examine the evidence only if the High Court has failed to apply correctly the principles governing appeals against acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: The true position is that if the High Court has set aside an order of acquittal, this Court in an appeal under article 136 from the judgment of the High Court will examine the evidence only if the High Court has failed to apply correctly the principles governing appeals against acquittal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes between routine re-appreciation and intervention when HC misapplies settled principles from precedents like Sheo Swarup; follows Privy Council and SC cases.

holdings.text: The High Court has full power to review the evidence upon which the order of acquittal was founded and to reach the conclusion that upon that evidence the order of acquittal should be reversed.

anchor.surface_text: Sections 417, 418 and 423 of the Code give to the High Court full power to review at large the evidence upon which the order of acquittal was founded, and to reach the conclusion that upon that evidence the order of acquittal should be reversed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of CrPC ss.417-423; no distinction between conviction and acquittal appeals; follows Sheo Swarup (Privy Council).

holdings.text: In exercising the power conferred by the Code and before reaching its conclusions upon fact, the High Court should and will always give proper weight and consideration to: (1) the views of the trial judge as to the credibility of the witnesses; (2) the presumption of innocence in favour of the accused; (3) the right of the accused to the benefit of any doubt; (4) the slowness of an appellate Court in disturbing a finding of fact arrived at by a judge who had the advantage of seeing the witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: But in exercising the power conferred by the Code and before reaching its conclusions upon fact, the High Court should and will always give proper weight and consideration to such matters as (1) the views of the trial judge as to the credibility of the witnesses; (2) the presumption of innocence in favour of the accused, a presumption certainly not weakened by the fact that he has been acquitted at his trial; (3) the right of the accused to the benefit of any doubt; and (4) the slowness of an appellate Court in disturbing a finding of fact arrived at by a judge who had the advantage of seeing the witnesses.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reaffirms Sheo Swarup guidelines; self-imposed limitations on plenary appellate power; presumption reinforced by acquittal.

holdings.text: The principles governing appeals against acquittal are thus firmly established and the issue cannot be re-opened.

anchor.surface_text: The principles governing appeals against acquittal are thus firmly established and the issue cannot be re-opened.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Survey of precedents from Sheo Swarup to Shivaji Bobade; consistent application without variation in approach.

holdings.text: In deciding appeals against acquittal the Court of Appeal must examine the evidence with particular care, must examine also the reasons on which the order of acquittal was based and should interfere with the order only when satisfied that the view taken by the acquitting Judge is clearly unreasonable.

anchor.surface_text: What may be called the golden thread running through all these decisions is the rule that in deciding appeals against acquittal the Court of Appeal must examine the evidence with particular care, must examine also the reasons on which the order of acquittal was based and should interfere with the order only when satisfied that the view taken by the acquitting Judge is clearly unreasonable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Golden thread from Harbans Singh; if two reasonable conclusions possible, do not disturb acquittal.

holdings.text: The High Court in the instant case was evidently aware of these principles but it failed to apply them to the case on hand.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in the instant case was evidently aware of these principles but it failed to apply them to the case on hand.

holdings.reasoning_summary: HC aware but did not weigh trial credibility findings, presumption, doubt; characterized trial finding as perverse wrongly.

holdings.text: The view taken by the learned Sessions Judge is clearly a reasonable view to take of the evidence.

anchor.surface_text: We will not proceed to show how the view taken by the learned Sessions Judge is clearly a reasonable view to take of the evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Detailed review of delay in FIR, Dwarika's conduct, routes, inconsistencies in witnesses Rampher, Kripal, Shanker; motive implausibility.

holdings.text: The principle of falsus in uno, falsus in omnibus is a principle that does not apply in our country.

anchor.surface_text: but that does not mean that Rampher's statement should be discarded for the principle of falsus in uno, falsus in omnibus is a principle that does not apply in our country.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Acknowledges rule not strict in India (obiter, as HC view quoted); but qualifies: caution required if fabrication evident.

holdings.text: For these reasons we are of the view that the High Court was not justified in interfering with the order of acquittal passed by the learned Sessions Judge.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we are of the view that the High Court was not justified in interfering with the order of acquittal passed by the learned Sessions Judge.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative: HC misapplied principles, trial view reasonable on delay, credibility, motive; restores acquittal.

precedents.case_name: Sheo Swarup v King-Emperor
precedents.cited_proposition: Code draws no distinction between appeal against acquittal and conviction as regards powers of High Court; full power to review evidence at large but give proper weight to trial judge views, presumption of innocence etc.
precedents.cited_holding: There is no foundation for the view that High Court has no power to reverse acquittal on fact except in cases of blunder etc.; full power under sections 417,418,423

anchor.surface_text: Sections 417, 418 and 423 of the Code give to the High Court full power to review at large the evidence upon which the order of acquittal was founded, and to reach the conclusion that upon that evidence the order of acquittal should be reversed.

anchor.surface_text: But in exercising the power conferred by the Code and before reaching its conclusions upon fact, the High Court should and will always give proper weight and consideration to such matters as (1) the views of the trial judge as to the credibility of the witnesses; (2) the presumption of innocence in favour of the accused, a presumption certainly not weakened by the fact that he has been acquitted at his trial; (3) the right of the accused to the benefit of any doubt; and (4) the slowness of an appellate Court in disturbing a finding of fact arrived at by a judge who had the advantage of seeing the witnesses.
For these reasons we are of the view that the High Court was number justified in interfering with the order of acquittal passed by the learned Sessions Judge.

anchor.surface_text: What may be called the golden thread running through all these decisions is the rule that in deciding appeals against acquittal the Court of Appeal must examine the evidence with particular care, must examine also the reasons on which the order of acquittal was based and should interfere with the order only when satisfied that the view taken by the acquitting Judge is clearly unreasonable.
For these reasons we are of the view that the High Court was number justified in interfering with the order of acquittal passed by the learned Sessions Judge.
